Case Name: Amarendra Komalam Vs. Usha Sinha
Issue Presented: Whether res judicata bars re-litigation of previously settled issue.
Facts of the Case: Concerned renewal clause of lease deed dated 02.09.1978 already addressed previously.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court permitted the respondent to reopen a previously waived issue.
Argument: Petitioner claimed res judicata, waiver, and estoppel prevented re-litigation.
Statute: Civil Procedure Code - Principles of Res Judicata.
Rules: Order 7, Rule 11 of CPC.
Precedent: SC ruling in S.L.P.(C) No. 16513/2001 cited.
Ratio of the Decision: Respondent waived the issue during prior court proceedings.
Ruling: Supreme Court barred re-litigation due to application of res judicata.

Case Name: Karnataka Rare Earth Vs. The Senior Geologist
Issue Presented: Dispute over the denial of mining lease renewal on environmental grounds.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner’s mining lease renewal rejected due to environmental concerns raised by the government.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the government’s decision based on environmental concerns.
Argument: Petitioner argues that the rejection was arbitrary, citing a lack of proper process and procedural fairness.
Rules: Rule 24A of Mineral Concession Rules, 1960.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court judgment on discretionary powers concerning mining leases.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that environmental concerns were more significant than the petitioner’s commercial interests.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that environmental issues justified the denial of renewal of the mining lease.

Case Name: Rajesh Kumar and Ors Vs. Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Respondent: Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Issue Presented: Legitimacy of a special audit order issued under Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act.
Facts of the Case: Raid on petitioner’s premises, documents seized, and assessment order mandating a special audit.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tribunal confirmed the validity of the special audit order.
Argument: Petitioner claimed that the special audit order lacked justifiable reasons and was arbitrary.
Rules: Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on the need for reasoned orders in taxation.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that the special audit order was invalid due to insufficient reasoning.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled against the special audit order, citing the absence of sufficient reasoning.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Surjit Singh
Issue Presented: Applicability of the equal pay for equal work doctrine.
Facts of the Case: Daily wage employees claimed equal pay to permanent employees despite irregular appointments.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employees, stating that equal pay for equal work should apply.
Argument: The State argued there was no formal recruitment process, and the appointments were irregular.
Statute: Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: Service Rules of Punjab Government.
Precedent: Ranbir Singh vs. State of Haryana.
Ratio of the Decision: Employees performing similar work, even on a daily wage basis, are entitled to a minimum pay scale.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s decision, favoring the employees’ claim for equal pay.

Case Name: Bengal Enamel Works Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal
Issue Presented: Dispute over the taxability of technical advisor’s remuneration.
Facts of the Case: Company paid technical advisor a profit-based remuneration, causing tax issues.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tax authorities deemed the payments excessive and disallowed the deductions.
Argument: Petitioner claimed the remuneration was justifiable considering the advisor’s expertise.
Rules: Section 40A(2) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Precedent cases involving reasonable remuneration expenses in tax laws.
Ratio of the Decision: Court found the payments unreasonable and ruled against the petitioner.
Ruling: Supreme Court agreed with the tax authority’s assessment and rejected the petitioner’s claims.

Case Name: Delhi Development Authority Vs. Skipper Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Fraudulent activities in property sale by construction company.
Facts of the Case: Company unlawfully collected funds from property buyers without proper authorization.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court directed refunds to buyers, ruling against the construction company.
Argument: Petitioner claimed the company misrepresented property rights and violated regulations.
Rules: Real Estate Development Rules.
Precedent: Prior cases on fraudulent practices and consumer rights in property transactions.
Ratio of the Decision: Court ruled that fraudulent actions required the company to pay penalties and make refunds.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed the order for refunds and imposed penalties on the company.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. R. Gandhi
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of NCLT and NCLAT establishment.
Facts of the Case: Challenge to the constitutionality of the creation of NCLT and NCLAT by the petitioner.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the NCLT's constitutional validity but recommended changes in appointments.
Argument: Petitioner claimed the establishment followed constitutional provisions for tribunals.
Rules: Tribunal Rules as per Companies Act provisions.
Precedent: Precedent regarding tribunal independence and separation of powers in constitutional law.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized the need for independent functioning of the tribunals.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed the NCLT's validity and directed changes in the appointment process.

Case Name: Lalita Kumari Vs. Government of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether police must register FIRs in cognizable offenses without preliminary inquiry.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s complaint regarding police refusal to register an FIR for a cognizable offense.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled FIR must be registered in all cognizable offenses.
Argument: Petitioner claimed that the police violated constitutional rights by failing to register an FIR.
Rules: Section 154 of CrPC.
Precedent: Precedents that affirm FIR registration is mandatory in cognizable offenses.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that FIR must be registered in all cognizable offenses without any preliminary inquiry.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed the mandatory registration of FIRs for cognizable offenses.

Case Name: Shreya Singhal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 66A of the Information Technology Act is unconstitutional.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner challenged Section 66A for being overly broad and violating fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Section 66A as necessary for cyber regulation.
Argument: Petitioner claimed that Section 66A was vague, arbitrary, and violated the freedom of speech.
Rules: Section 66A of the IT Act.
Precedent: Previous Supreme Court rulings on the right to free speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Ratio of the Decision: The law must not be vague, and fundamental rights cannot be restricted without clear guidelines.
Ruling: Supreme Court declared Section 66A unconstitutional due to its broad and arbitrary nature.

Case Name: Vishaka & Ors Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Whether guidelines should be framed for the prevention of workplace sexual harassment.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner sought protective measures after an employee was subjected to sexual harassment.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed the PIL, citing no specific laws on workplace harassment.
Argument: The absence of specific legislation does not remove the obligation to protect rights.
Rules: Vishaka Guidelines framed by the Supreme Court.
Precedent: No prior law existed to govern workplace sexual harassment.
Ratio of the Decision: The lack of a specific law does not absolve the state from creating protective guidelines.
Ruling: Supreme Court established the Vishaka Guidelines for the prevention of workplace sexual harassment.

Case Name: Aruna Shanbaug Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether passive euthanasia should be legally permitted in India.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner sought legal intervention for withdrawal of life support for Aruna Shanbaug.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against the petitioner's plea for euthanasia.
Argument: Petition argued that the continuation of life support violates the dignity of the patient.
Rules: Guidelines proposed for reviewing passive euthanasia requests.
Precedent: No direct ruling on euthanasia before this case.
Ratio of the Decision: Passive euthanasia may be permitted under regulated conditions.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed passive euthanasia, setting guidelines for its application.

Case Name: Navtej Singh Johar Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code criminalizing consensual same-sex relations is constitutional.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner challenged the criminalization of consensual same-sex relationships under Section 377.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of decriminalization of Section 377.
Argument: Petitioner argued that Section 377 violated fundamental rights, including dignity and privacy.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under the Constitution of India.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the right to privacy and equality under the Indian Constitution.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court upheld the decriminalization of consensual same-sex relationships.
Ruling: Supreme Court decriminalized consensual same-sex relationships under Section 377.

Case Name: Maneka Gandhi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the impoundment of Maneka Gandhi’s passport violated her personal liberty under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The government impounded the petitioner’s passport, and she argued it violated her right to personal liberty under Article 21.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the government.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the action violated the scope of Article 21, and lacked due process.
Rules: The law must ensure fairness and due process when restricting personal liberty.
Precedent: Precedents on personal liberty and judicial interpretations of Article 21.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling expanded the scope of Article 21, emphasizing due process and fairness in state actions affecting liberty.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, expanding the scope of personal liberty under Article 21.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the company is liable for environmental pollution caused by oleum gas leakage.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the company should be held accountable for the industrial disaster.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court imposed fines on the company, addressing liability for the pollution.
Argument: Petitioner argued for corporate accountability for hazardous activities and stricter environmental laws.
Rules: Strict liability and absolute liability principles for industrial activities causing harm.
Precedent: Reference to the Bhopal Gas Tragedy case on environmental and corporate liability.
Ratio of the Decision: The introduction of the 'absolute liability' principle for industries causing environmental hazards.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that industries must bear absolute liability for hazardous activities.

Case Name: Olga Tellis Vs. Bombay Municipal Corporation
Issue Presented: Right to livelihood under Article 21 of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Slum dwellers contested the eviction orders, arguing the loss of livelihood.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court favored municipal authorities in eviction matters.
Argument: Petitioner argued forced eviction violated their right to life and livelihood under Article 21.
Rules: Municipal regulations related to eviction.
Precedent: Precedents regarding eviction and right to life in relation to shelter and livelihood.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to livelihood is part of the right to life, ensuring no eviction without alternative provisions.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated that before eviction, the state must provide reasonable alternatives.

Case Name: Indra Sawhney Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of OBC reservations and exclusion of the 'creamy layer'.
Facts of the Case: The Mandal Commission's 27% recommendation for OBC reservation was contested on the grounds that it exceeded the reservation limit.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the reservation policy.
Argument: Petitioner argued that such excessive reservations were unconstitutional and violated equality.
Rules: Government reservation policy and criteria for exclusion of the 'creamy layer'.
Precedent: Past rulings on the legitimacy of affirmative action and ensuring fair representation.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservations for OBCs are valid, but the 'creamy layer' must be excluded to ensure equity.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the validity of OBC reservations while excluding the 'creamy layer' from its benefits.

Case Name: Minerva Mills Ltd. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Balancing Directive Principles and Fundamental Rights.
Facts of the Case: Amendments to the Constitution challenged as violating the basic structure doctrine.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the constitutional amendments.
Argument: Petitioner contended amendments should not destroy fundamental rights, violating the basic structure doctrine.
Rules: Basic structure doctrine and its application in the context of constitutional amendments.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala and other precedents related to the basic structure doctrine.
Ratio of the Decision: Directive Principles are subservient to Fundamental Rights under the basic structure doctrine.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that parts of the amendment violated the Constitution and were struck down.

Case Name: ADM Jabalpur Vs. Shivkant Shukla
Issue Presented: Suspension of fundamental rights during Emergency.
Facts of the Case: Detentions without trial during the Emergency raised concerns about the violation of the right to life and liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court favored the petitioners, asserting that fundamental rights should not be suspended during the Emergency.
Argument: Petitioner argued that fundamental rights should not be suspended, even during an Emergency.
Rules: Legal precedents concerning the suspension of rights during national emergencies.
Precedent: Precedents regarding the suspension of rights during emergencies and their legal limits.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights cannot be suspended during an Emergency, with judicial oversight and protection.
Ruling: Supreme Court initially upheld the suspension of fundamental rights during Emergency, though this was overruled in later judgments.

Case Name: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Extent of Parliament's power to amend the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the constitutionality of land reform laws and argued that Parliament cannot alter fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the land reform laws but did not address the limitation on Parliament’s power to amend fundamental rights.
Argument: Petitioner contended that any amendment by Parliament that alters the basic structure of the Constitution is unconstitutional.
Rules: Basic structure doctrine and laws related to constitutional amendments.
Precedent: No previous ruling on limiting the scope of constitutional amendments.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that Parliament's power to amend the Constitution is limited by the basic structure doctrine.
Ruling: The Supreme Court enshrined the basic structure doctrine, preventing Parliament from altering the fundamental features of the Constitution.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Taj Trapezium Case)
Issue Presented: Protection of the Taj Mahal from environmental pollution.
Facts of the Case: Pollution from surrounding industries was damaging the Taj Mahal, necessitating action for its protection.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court directed industries to take steps for pollution control and protect the Taj Mahal.
Argument: Petitioner argued for the relocation of polluting industries around the Taj Mahal to prevent further damage.
Rules: Air and Water Pollution Control Rules.
Precedent: Previous rulings on heritage site protection, environmental conservation, and pollution control.
Ratio of the Decision: The protection of heritage sites, such as the Taj Mahal, is essential and requires addressing environmental pollution.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated that polluting industries near the Taj Mahal must be relocated to preserve the integrity of the site.

Case Name: DK Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Guidelines for the protection of arrested individuals.
Facts of the Case: The petition was filed in response to reports of custodial abuse, seeking guidelines to protect arrested individuals.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court recommended specific guidelines for police procedures and custodial safety.
Argument: Petitioner sought the introduction of measures to prevent custodial torture and ensure detainees' safety.
Rules: Guidelines on the treatment of detainees and arrest procedures.
Precedent: Previous rulings on custodial abuse and human rights protection in detention.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights, under Article 21, apply to individuals under arrest, guaranteeing protection from inhuman treatment.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated specific procedural safeguards to prevent custodial torture and protect detainees' rights.

Case Name: Lily Thomas Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Disqualification of convicted legislators.
Facts of the Case: The petition challenged Section 8(4) of the Representation of the People Act, arguing that convicted legislators should be disqualified immediately.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the provision allowing convicted legislators to remain in office while appealing.
Argument: Petitioner contended that Section 8(4) should be struck down to ensure convicted legislators are immediately disqualified.
Rules: Disqualification rules for convicted individuals under electoral laws.
Precedent: Past judgments on the disqualification of legislators and maintaining electoral integrity.
Ratio of the Decision: Allowing convicted legislators to remain in office undermines democratic values and governance integrity.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled to strike down Section 8(4) of the Representation of the People Act, enforcing immediate disqualification for convicted lawmakers.

Case Name: Peopleâ€™s Union for Civil Liberties Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Right to privacy in telephone tapping cases.
Facts of the Case: PUCL argued that the government’s unrestricted power to tap phones violated privacy rights under Article 21.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the government’s authority to intercept communications for national security.
Argument: Petitioner contended that phone tapping without safeguards violates the right to privacy.
Rules: Rules regarding surveillance, interception, and phone tapping for national security.
Precedent: Legal precedents related to privacy and the right to freedom of speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Phone tapping constitutes an invasion of privacy and must be conducted with procedural safeguards.
Ruling: Supreme Court emphasized the need for clear legal safeguards before phone tapping can be conducted.

Case Name: S. R. Bommai Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: The President dismissed the Karnataka government, citing Article 356, leading to challenges regarding the central government’s control over states.
Facts of the Case: The Karnataka government was dismissed by the President under Article 356, raising concerns over misuse of central authority.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the imposition of President’s rule by the central government.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the use of Article 356 was arbitrary and violated the principles of federalism.
Rules: Rules regarding presidential powers in the context of state governance.
Precedent: Earlier decisions on the misuse of Article 356 and the role of judicial review.
Ratio of the Decision: The imposition of President’s rule under Article 356 is subject to judicial scrutiny to prevent arbitrary action.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that presidential action under Article 356 must be justifiable and subject to judicial review.

Case Name: Mohd. Ahmed Khan Vs. Shah Bano Begum
Issue Presented: Right of a Muslim woman to maintenance under Section 125 CrPC.
Facts of the Case: Shah Bano, divorced by her husband, sought maintenance under Section 125 CrPC after being denied by her husband, citing Muslim Personal Law limitations.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court granted Shah Bano maintenance, ruling that Section 125 CrPC applies regardless of religion.
Argument: Petitioner argued that maintenance rights should be governed by Muslim Personal Law, which limits support beyond the iddat period.
Rules: Section 125 of CrPC, Muslim Personal Law governing divorce and maintenance.
Precedent: Prior rulings on the scope of maintenance for divorced women under Section 125 CrPC.
Ratio of the Decision: A woman, regardless of her religion, is entitled to maintenance under Section 125 CrPC if she is unable to maintain herself.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Shah Bano's right to maintenance, asserting that Section 125 CrPC applies universally.

Case Name: I. R. Coelho Vs. State of Tamil Nadu
Issue Presented: Whether laws placed in the Ninth Schedule are subject to judicial review.
Facts of the Case: The State of Tamil Nadu had placed laws in the Ninth Schedule, avoiding judicial scrutiny, which the petitioner argued violated fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the immunity of laws placed in the Ninth Schedule from judicial review.
Argument: Petitioner argued that laws placed in the Ninth Schedule should not be shielded from judicial scrutiny if they violate fundamental rights.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 31B and Ninth Schedule.
Rules: Article 31B and the Ninth Schedule provisions for safeguarding laws.
Precedent: Precedents on judicial review, especially the Kesavananda Bharati case and Basic Structure Doctrine.
Ratio of the Decision: Laws placed in the Ninth Schedule must conform to the Constitution’s Basic Structure, and any violation of fundamental rights is subject to judicial review.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that laws in the Ninth Schedule are not entirely immune to judicial review, especially if they violate the Constitution’s Basic Structure.

Case Name: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Environmental pollution caused by tannery industries in Tamil Nadu.
Facts of the Case: Tanneries caused widespread water contamination, harming both public health and the environment.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of compensation for affected communities due to pollution.
Argument: etitioner argued that industries must bear the cost of environmental damage caused by their activities.
Rules: Polluter Pays Principle, Precautionary Principle, and environmental protection laws.
Precedent: Rulings on corporate accountability in environmental matters and application of the Polluter Pays Principle.
Ratio of the Decision: Industries causing environmental harm must compensate affected individuals and take corrective measures.
Ruling: Supreme Court enforced stricter regulations on tanneries, applying the Polluter Pays Principle for compensation.

Case Name: Naz Foundation Vs. Government of NCT of Delhi
Issue Presented: Decriminalization of same-sex relationships and challenging Section 377 of the IPC.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that Section 377 IPC criminalized consensual same-sex acts and violated the right to equality, dignity, and privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: Delhi High Court decriminalized homosexuality, finding Section 377 unconstitutional.
Argument: The petition argued that Section 377 violated fundamental rights under Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21 by criminalizing private, consensual acts.
Rules: Rights under Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21 of the Constitution of India.
Precedent: Previous cases involving personal liberty, privacy, and non-discrimination.
Ratio of the Decision: Section 377 violates constitutional rights, including the right to equality and dignity, and must be decriminalized.
Ruling: Delhi High Court ruled Section 377 unconstitutional, decriminalizing same-sex relations.

Case Name: Puttaswamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Challenge to the Aadhaar scheme, claiming it violated the right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that Aadhaar, by collecting biometric and personal data, infringed upon the fundamental right to privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the constitutionality of the Aadhaar scheme, stating it did not violate privacy rights.
Argument: The petitioner contended that privacy is integral to life and personal liberty, and Aadhaar violated that privacy by extensive data collection.
Rules: Rights to privacy, data protection, and autonomy under the Indian Constitution.
Precedent: Previous cases involving individual privacy, autonomy, and government surveillance powers.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to privacy is an essential and fundamental right under Article 21 of the Constitution.
Ruling: Supreme Court recognized the right to privacy as a fundamental right, invalidating state surveillance without adequate safeguards.

Case Name: Keshub Mahindra Vs. Union of India (Bhopal Gas Tragedy Case)
Issue Presented: Legal responsibility of corporations in industrial disasters involving hazardous substances.
Facts of the Case: A gas leak from Union Carbide's Bhopal plant caused mass casualties, raising issues of corporate and criminal liability.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court penalized the company but diluted criminal charges against top executives.
Argument: The petitioner claimed the incident was unforeseen and not the result of deliberate negligence or intent.
Rules: Laws concerning environmental protection, corporate accountability, and liability in industrial accidents.
Precedent: MC Mehta v. Union of India established absolute liability in hazardous industrial activities.
Ratio of the Decision: Enterprises engaging in dangerous activities owe an absolute duty to ensure no harm, irrespective of fault.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered compensation for victims and emphasized absolute liability of Union Carbide.

Case Name: Golaknath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament can amend or abridge fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: Petitioners contested a constitutional amendment placing land laws under the Ninth Schedule, claiming it infringed on their rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that Parliament had constitutional authority to make the amendment.
Argument: Petitioners maintained that Parliament cannot use Article 368 to dilute fundamental rights.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 368 and Fundamental Rights.
Rules: Amendment powers are subject to implied limitations when affecting fundamental rights.
Precedent: Prior judgments had allowed broad amendment powers; no restriction yet defined.
Ratio of the Decision: Parliament cannot curtail fundamental rights via constitutional amendment.
Ruling: Supreme Court restricted Parliament’s power to amend fundamental rights, but the ruling was later overruled.

Case Name: Union Carbide Corporation Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the $470 million compensation settlement was just and constitutionally valid.
Facts of the Case: A settlement of $470 million was reached between Union Carbide and the Indian government for Bhopal gas victims; questions arose over its adequacy and legal validity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court accepted the settlement but victim groups challenged its sufficiency.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the agreed compensation was lawful, final, and fairly negotiated.
Statute: Bhopal Gas Leak Disaster (Processing of Claims) Act, 1985.
Rules: Absolute liability doctrine, just compensation principles under tort and constitutional law.
Precedent: Past decisions on industrial liability and state responsibility for mass torts.
Ratio of the Decision: Compensation must be adequate, but Supreme Court allowed scope for future claims due to ongoing harm.
Ruling: Supreme Court validated the settlement but kept the door open for future claims due to continuing injuries or under-assessment.

Case Name: Sheela Barse Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Protection of women prisoners from custodial violence.
Facts of the Case: Journalist Sheela Barse filed a PIL after reporting abuse of women prisoners in Maharashtra.
Ruling by Lower Court: Recommended reforms but did not enforce strict guidelines.
Argument: Claimed custodial abuse violated Article 21 and demanded safeguards.
Statute: Article 21 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: Guidelines on prisoner rights and custodial safety.
Precedent: DK Basu case on custodial violence.
Ratio of the Decision: Women prisoners are entitled to dignity and protection under Article 21.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated reforms for better treatment and monitoring of women in custody.

Case Name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutional validity of bonded labor and state responsibility to address it.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed highlighting the exploitation of bonded laborers in degrading conditions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court provided interim relief but avoided systemic directions.
Argument: The petitioner claimed bonded labor violated Articles 21 and 23, demanding strong state action.
Rules: Constitutional and statutory provisions related to forced labor.
Precedent: Earlier Supreme Court rulings on forced labor and labor rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Bonded labor violates fundamental rights and demands state-led rehabilitation.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated proactive measures for identification, release, and rehabilitation of bonded laborers.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Krishna Kumar
Issue Presented: Whether the denial of reservation under the education policy violated the right to education.
Facts of the Case: State's policy denied reservation benefits to a group of students, leading to a legal challenge.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court sided with the students, holding that reservations were essential for equality in education.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the denial was necessary to maintain efficiency.
Rules: Reservation provisions in educational institutions framed under the Constitution and statutory laws.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney & other relevant cases on reservation and affirmative action in education.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that denial of reservations violates the right to education and must be remedied.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed the state to revise its education policy to include fair reservation provisions.

Case Name: Ramesh Dalal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether convicted legislators should be disqualified immediately.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that permitting convicted legislators to remain in office during the appeal process undermines democratic integrity.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court maintained the status quo, permitting legislators to remain in office until appeals concluded.
Argument: Petitioners maintained that immediate disqualification is necessary to preserve public trust and democracy.
Rules: Clear disqualification provisions for convicted public officials.
Precedent: Lily Thomas and related rulings on immediate disqualification in electoral law.
Ratio of the Decision: Immediate disqualification is required to uphold the integrity of the electoral system.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated that upon conviction, MPs and MLAs must be disqualified.

Case Name: Mohini Jain Vs. State of Karnataka
Issue Presented: Whether high capitation fees in private medical colleges violate the fundamental right to education.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed against exorbitant capitation fees limiting access to medical education.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the fee structure under existing regulations.
Argument: Petitioner contended that financial barriers in education violate the principle of equal access to education.
Rules: Guidelines governing fee structures for private educational institutions.
Precedent: Unni Krishnan case emphasizing education as a fundamental right.
Ratio of the Decision: Capitation fees that limit access are unconstitutional.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled capitation fees unconstitutional, reinforcing the right to education.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Madhukar Narayan Mardikar
Issue Presented: Right to privacy and protection of women’s dignity.
Facts of the Case: A woman, denied legal protection because of her profession, raised concerns about equality and dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld her right to legal protection.
Argument: Argued that a woman’s occupation should not diminish her entitlement to fundamental rights.
Rules: Fundamental Rights and Women’s Protection Laws.
Precedent: Precedents on gender equality and the right to dignity.
Ratio of the Decision: All women, irrespective of their profession, are entitled to equal protection and dignity.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed that the right to dignity and privacy extends equally to all women.

Case Name: Jarnail Singh Vs. Lachhmi Narain Gupta
Issue Presented: Whether reservation in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Facts of the Case: The case challenged the validity of reservations in promotions without data-driven evidence of backwardness.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against unquantified reservations in promotions.
Argument: Petitioner contended that reservation policies must be supported by data to prove backwardness before implementation.
Rules: Reservation policies in public employment requiring evidence-based justification.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney case on reservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservations in promotions must be substantiated with quantifiable evidence of backwardness.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed that reservations in promotions require measurable data to justify the policy.

Case Name: Gian Kaur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether abetment of suicide under Section 306 IPC violates Article 21.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner claimed that the right to life includes the right to die.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held Section 306 IPC unconstitutional.
Argument: Petitioner argued personal liberty includes the right to die.
Rules: Right to Life under Article 21.
Precedent: P. Rathinam case.
Ratio of the Decision: Article 21 does not imply a right to die.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Section 306 IPC and confirmed that abetment of suicide is a punishable offense.

Case Name: K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) Vs. Union of India (Aadhaar Case)
Issue Presented: Does mandatory Aadhaar linking violate the right to privacy under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: Challenge against Aadhaar’s compulsory use for welfare and services, citing violation of privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Aadhaar scheme.
Argument: Aadhaar violates informational autonomy and personal privacy.
Rules: Aadhaar Act, 2016.
Precedent: Prior judgments affirming privacy as intrinsic to dignity.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to privacy is fundamental; state must ensure proportionality in data collection.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Aadhaar but limited mandatory usage to subsidies and government benefits.

Case Name: Shayara Bano Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether instant triple talaq violates fundamental rights under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Shayara Bano contested the practice of talaq-e-biddat (instant triple talaq) on grounds of discrimination.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld its validity under personal law.
Argument: Petitioner claimed triple talaq is unjust, violates dignity and equality.
Rules: Muslim Personal Law (Shariat) Application Act, 1937.
Precedent: Past cases recognizing gender justice in personal law interpretation.
Ratio of the Decision: The practice is manifestly arbitrary and violates fundamental rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court declared instant triple talaq unconstitutional and invalid.

Case Name: Common Cause Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether passive euthanasia and living wills are constitutionally valid.
Facts of the Case: Common Cause filed a petition seeking recognition of passive euthanasia and the right to living wills.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court rejected passive euthanasia as unconstitutional.
Argument: Petitioner contended that right to die with dignity should include the right to refuse life support.
Rules: Proposed legal framework for passive euthanasia and living wills.
Precedent: Aruna Shanbaug case allowed limited passive euthanasia with court approval.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to die with dignity is an integral part of Article 21.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed passive euthanasia and validated living wills under strict safeguards.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Kamal Nath
Issue Presented: Whether private construction on riverbeds violates environmental and public trust principles.
Facts of the Case: Construction of a private resort led to river diversion and ecological harm in forest land.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court levied a penalty but did not halt the resort project.
Argument: Petitioner claimed the resort infringed public rights over natural resources and damaged the river.
Rules: Doctrine of Public Trust and sustainable development principles.
Precedent: Earlier judgments affirming that environment must be protected for public benefit.
Ratio of the Decision: Public Trust Doctrine prohibits private exploitation of natural resources like rivers and forests.
Ruling: Supreme Court invoked Public Trust Doctrine and ordered restoration of the riverbed and forest.

Case Name: State of Tamil Nadu Vs. K. Balu
Issue Presented: Whether liquor shops near highways contribute to road accidents and should be regulated.
Facts of the Case: A PIL sought removal of liquor outlets within 500 meters of highways to reduce traffic fatalities.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court allowed current licensing policies to continue.
Argument: Petitioner asserted liquor shops near highways increased drunk driving and road hazards.
Rules: Road Safety Guidelines and Liquor Licensing Laws.
Precedent: Previous rulings on balancing public safety with commercial interests.
Ratio of the Decision: Public interest and safety outweigh the right to conduct liquor trade near highways.
Ruling: Supreme Court banned liquor shops within 500 meters of highways for safety reasons.

Case Name: Delhi Transport Corporation Vs. DTC Mazdoor Congress
Issue Presented: Whether the dismissal of employees without due process violated principles of natural justice.
Facts of the Case: Employees were terminated without inquiry or justification, raising concerns of unfair labor practices.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found the dismissals illegal and ordered reinstatement with benefits.
Argument: DTC contended that it had the authority to terminate based on organizational needs.
Rules: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Precedent: Landmark decisions requiring fair procedure in labor dismissals.
Ratio of the Decision: Arbitrary dismissal violates Article 14 and principles of fairness.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed reinstatement, emphasizing the need for fair inquiry before termination.

Case Name: State of Uttar Pradesh Vs. Raj Narain
Issue Presented: Whether citizens have the right to access government documents in the interest of transparency.
Facts of the Case: Raj Narain demanded access to confidential government documents related to election expenses.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld citizen's right to access election-related government records.
Argument: State claimed disclosure would compromise national interest and confidentiality.
Rules: Laws supporting public right to know in a democracy.
Precedent: Earlier cases recognizing citizens’ right to access public records.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to information is inherent in freedom of speech and expression.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed transparency.

Case Name: M. Nagaraj Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether reservation in promotions violates meritocracy without data-based justification.
Facts of the Case: Challenge to reservation in promotions without assessing backwardness and administrative efficiency.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court supported reservation in promotions.
Argument: Petitioner claimed promotions must be backed by data proving backwardness and inadequate representation.
Rules: Rules concerning equality of opportunity and affirmative action in promotions.
Precedent: Indra Sawhney and other precedents emphasizing data-backed reservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservation in promotions is valid only with quantifiable proof of backwardness.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed reservations in promotions, subject to proof of backwardness and impact review.

Case Name: Joseph Shine Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 497 IPC violates gender equality.
Facts of the Case: Section 497 IPC was challenged for treating women unequally and infringing on liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court maintained the law's constitutionality.
Argument: Petitioner claimed adultery law was discriminatory and violated fundamental rights.
Rules: Articles 14, 15, 21 of the Constitution.
Precedent: Earlier cases on individual liberty and gender neutrality in law.
Ratio of the Decision: Law treating women as passive victims violates equality and dignity.
Ruling: Supreme Court declared Section 497 unconstitutional and decriminalized adultery.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether TADA violates fundamental rights by allowing prolonged detention without adequate safeguards.
Facts of the Case: TADA permitted detention without trial, prompting constitutional scrutiny regarding personal liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld TADA’s constitutionality.
Argument: Petitioner claimed TADA allowed arbitrary state power, undermining due process and individual rights.
Rules: Articles 14 and 21 – Right to Equality and Personal Liberty
Precedent: Case law on preventive detention and constitutional limits on anti-terror statutes.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights must be balanced with national security.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld TADA but mandated procedural safeguards to prevent misuse and protect rights.

Case Name: Nandini Satpathy Vs. P.L. Dani
Issue Presented: Whether compelling an accused to answer during interrogation violates Article 20(3).
Facts of the Case: Petitioner declined to answer questions, citing protection from self-incrimination.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held refusal to answer could justify adverse inference.
Argument: Petitioner claimed Article 20(3) protected her from being compelled to answer.
Rules: Self-incrimination protections under criminal procedure.
Precedent: Jurisprudence reinforcing protection against compelled testimony.
Ratio of the Decision: Compelled interrogation violates the right against self-incrimination.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the petitioner’s right under Article 20(3).

Case Name: Sarla Mudgal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether conversion to Islam permits bigamy for Hindus.
Facts of the Case: A Hindu man embraced Islam to remarry without divorcing his first wife.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court recognized the second marriage under Muslim law.
Argument: Petitioner opposed misuse of religious conversion to bypass monogamy laws.
Rules: Bigamy restrictions under personal laws.
Precedent: Cases involving religious conversion and marriage.
Ratio of the Decision: Religious conversion cannot be a tool to evade monogamy provisions.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that prior Hindu marriage remains valid despite conversion.

Case Name: Visakha Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Legal protection against workplace sexual harassment.
Facts of the Case: A PIL followed a sexual harassment incident, highlighting absence of legal protection.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court rejected the plea due to no existing legislation.
Argument: Petitioner emphasized state’s duty to ensure women’s safety regardless of law.
Rules: Fundamental rights mandate workplace protection.
Precedent: No comprehensive precedent existed before this ruling.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court recognized the need for interim protection in absence of legislation.
Ruling: Vishaka Guidelines were established to protect women at the workplace.

Case Name: Bachan Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Validity of death penalty under Indian law.
Facts of the Case: Death penalty under Section 302 IPC was challenged as unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the punishment.
Argument: Argued it violated right to life under Article 21.
Rules: Rarest of rare doctrine.
Precedent: Earlier rulings on capital punishment.
Ratio of the Decision: Death penalty allowed only in rarest of rare cases.
Ruling: Death penalty upheld with strict guidelines.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Dalbir Singh
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of mandatory death sentence under NDPS Act.
Facts of the Case: NDPS Act provision mandating death sentence was challenged.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the NDPS provision.
Argument: Argued mandatory sentencing removes judicial discretion.
Rules: Sentencing principles in criminal jurisprudence.
Precedent: Bachan Singh on rarest of rare standard.
Ratio of the Decision: Mandatory death sentences unconstitutional due to lack of discretion.
Ruling: Supreme Court invalidated the mandatory death penalty clause.

Case Name: State (Delhi Administration) Vs. Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Another
Respondent: Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Ram Kishan Alias Phokan
Issue Presented: Legality of High Court's acquittal despite existing evidence.
Facts of the Case: Accused involved in a fatal stabbing; High Court acquitted them citing doubt.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court acquitted both accused.
Argument: Prosecution failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt.
Rules: Proof beyond reasonable doubt is essential for murder conviction.
Precedent: No key precedent cited.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court found evidence sufficient for conviction.
Ruling: Conviction under IPC 326; 6 years rigorous imprisonment awarded.

Case Name: Ram Saran Dass Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether termination was a punitive dismissal requiring Article 311(2) protection.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner was terminated without hearing; alleged mala fide dismissal.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court dismissed petition without hearing respondent.
Argument: Termination violated natural justice and Article 311(2).
Rules: Service Rule 23 Conditions for termination.
Precedent: Cited precedents on natural justice and disguised dismissal.
Ratio of the Decision: High Court erred in denying hearing to respondent; natural justice applies.
Ruling: Appeal allowed; matter remanded for fresh hearing.

Case Name: Credit Agricole Indosuez Vs. Credential Finance Limited
Issue Presented: Can non-credit of cleared cheque justify winding-up under Companies Act.
Facts of the Case: Bank alleged failure to credit cheque; sought winding-up of company.
Ruling by Lower Court: Petition for winding up was dismissed.
Argument: Respondent claimed valid reasons for not crediting the cheque.
Rules: Rules on cheque clearance under corporate insolvency.
Precedent: Case law on cheque dishonor and debt recovery.
Ratio of the Decision: Non-credit of cheque alone doesn't prove inability to pay debts.
Ruling: Dismissal upheld; appeal pending.

Case Name: A.K. Gopalan Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of preventive detention under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: Gopalan was detained without trial and challenged the detention law.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the law.
Argument: Detention without trial violates personal liberty.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: First major ruling on preventive detention.
Ratio of the Decision: Article 21 allows preventive detention if procedure is lawful.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld detention law; later cases expanded Article 21

Case Name: State of West Bengal Vs. Anwar Ali Sarkar
Issue Presented: Validity of special courts under Article 14.
Facts of the Case: Law allowed selective referral of cases to special courts.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court struck down the law.
Argument: Argued selective referrals violated equality before law.
Rules: Due process and non-discrimination principles.
Precedent: Early precedent on misuse of special courts
Ratio of the Decision: Special courts must not be arbitrary or discriminatory.
Ruling: Supreme Court declared the law unconstitutional.

Case Name: Kedar Nath Singh Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Constitutional validity of sedition under Article 19(1)(a).
Facts of the Case: Conviction for anti-government speeches under Section 124A IPC.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld conviction.
Argument: Argued sedition law suppresses dissent.
Rules: Freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a) and restrictions.
Precedent: Early interpretations of sedition and free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Only speech inciting violence qualifies as sedition.
Ruling: Section 124A upheld, but narrowed to violent incitement.

Case Name: Bharat Singh Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Legality of land acquisition and adequacy of compensation.
Facts of the Case: Agricultural land was acquired; petitioner contested the public purpose and compensation.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled acquisition valid.
Argument: Argued acquisition violated property rights and fairness.
Rules: Acquisition must be for public purpose with compensation.
Precedent: Cases affirming fair compensation in land acquisition.
Ratio of the Decision: Acquisition valid but must include just compensation.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld acquisition but insisted on fairness.

Case Name: Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether NJAC violates judicial independence under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: NJAC sought to replace the collegium system for appointing judges.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of NJAC.
Argument: Petitioners claimed NJAC diluted judicial primacy in appointments.
Rules: Separation of powers and judicial independence doctrine.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati case on basic structure.
Ratio of the Decision: Judicial primacy in appointments is essential to independence.
Ruling: NJAC Act and 99th Constitutional Amendment struck down.

Case Name: Laxmi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the state must regulate acid sales to protect women under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, an acid attack survivor, sought stricter control over acid sales and victim support.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court acknowledged the problem but did not impose new restrictions.
Argument: Petitioner argued unrestricted acid access violated right to life and dignity.
Rules: Guidelines on sale restrictions and state obligation to rehabilitate victims.
Precedent: Cases emphasizing state duty to protect dignity and bodily integrity.
Ratio of the Decision: Protection from acid attacks is essential to securing dignity under Article 21.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed strict licensing for acid sales and mandated victim compensation and rehabilitation.

Case Name: Tamil Nadu Govt. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether central laws encroached upon state powers in education under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Tamil Nadu government challenged certain central laws affecting state education policies.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld central authority over education.
Argument: State contended that education should be a state subject under the Constitution.
Rules: Entries in the Concurrent List relating to education.
Precedent: Precedents on cooperative federalism and division of legislative competence.
Ratio of the Decision: Central laws are valid under the Concurrent List, but state autonomy in education policy is also recognized.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld central laws but allowed states flexibility in educational matters.

Case Name: Subramanian Swamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Constitutionality of criminal defamation laws under Article 19(1)(a).
Facts of the Case: Swamy contended that criminalizing defamation curtailed free expression.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found no constitutional infirmity in criminal defamation laws.
Argument: Criminal defamation imposes a chilling effect on speech and violates fundamental rights.
Rules: Article 19(2) – Reasonable restrictions on freedom of speech.
Precedent: Prior decisions interpreting reasonable restrictions on free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Protecting reputation and a legitimate ground for restricting speech.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity.

Case Name: Ram Jawaya Kapur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the executive can carry out functions without legislative sanction.
Facts of the Case: The Punjab government started publishing textbooks without legislative backing.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held that executive action was permissible in absence of legislation.
Argument: The petitioner contended that executive action in commercial matters required legislative support.
Rules: Executive power is co-extensive with legislative power unless limited by statute.
Precedent: No prior binding precedent; case clarified scope of executive powers.
Ratio of the Decision: The executive can act where the legislature is silent, but not contrary to existing laws.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the government's action, but not in violation of it.

Case Name: State of Bihar Vs. K.K. Misra
Issue Presented: Whether government employees have a fundamental right to strike.
Facts of the Case: Government employees participated in a statewide strike over pay disputes.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held the strike was not illegal and provided relief to employees.
Argument: The state argued that government employees do not have an absolute right to strike.
Rules: Limitations on rights of government servants under service conduct rules and ESMA.
Precedent: Previous rulings on employees' rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to strike is not a fundamental right for government employees.
Ruling: Supreme Court reversed the High Court’s order, holding that strikes are not constitutionally protected in this context.

Case Name: Sundararamier & Co. Vs. State of Andhra Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether the State can levy tax on inter-state trade under its sales tax law.
Facts of the Case: The company was taxed under the Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act on goods involved in inter-state commerce.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of the state sales tax law.
Argument: Petitioner contended that only Parliament has the power to tax inter-state trade.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 286; Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act.
Rules: Article 286 prohibits states from taxing inter-state trade and commerce.
Precedent: Prior Supreme Court interpretations of inter-state trade.
Ratio of the Decision: State laws taxing inter-state trade are unconstitutional unless authorized by Parliament.
Ruling: Supreme Court held the state sales tax law unconstitutional to the extent it taxed inter-state sales.

Case Name: Golak Nath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament has the power to amend Fundamental Rights of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner challenged constitutional amendments that curtailed fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the validity of the constitutional amendment.
Argument: Petitioners argued that Article 368 does not grant power to abridge fundamental rights.
Rules: Fundamental Rights cannot be amended as they form the core of the Constitution.
Precedent: Earlier decisions allowed amending FRs.
Ratio of the Decision: Parliament cannot amend Fundamental Rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that Parliament had no power to amend.

Case Name: Shankarappa Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the Union Government can override decisions of the (FCAT) under the Cinematograph Act.
Facts of the Case: A film was denied certification by the Censor Board, citing public order concerns.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the Central Government's override of the FCAT decision.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the government's power to override FCAT decisions is arbitrary and violates freedom of speech.
Rules: Principles of reasonable restriction under Article 19(2).
Precedent: Earlier judgments emphasizing the limited scope of censorship in a democratic society.
Ratio of the Decision: The government cannot arbitrarily reverse a certification granted by an expert tribunal like FCAT.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that the Censor Board cannot be overridden by the government arbitrarily.

Case Name: Madhu Limaye Vs. Sub-Divisional Magistrate
Issue Presented: Whether frequent and preventive use of Section 144 CrPC and freedom of speech.
Facts of the Case: Section 144 was imposed to prevent a political meeting, which the petitioner claimed infringed on constitutional freedoms.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held that the executive had acted within its powers.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the provision was being misused to stifle free speech and assembly.
Rules: Reasonable restrictions under Articles 19(2) and 19(3).
Precedent: Judicial interpretation of preventive powers vs constitutional freedoms.
Ratio of the Decision: Section 144 is constitutionally valid must be used only in exceptional situations and not as a routine measure.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled the validity of Section 144 but restricted its arbitrary use.

Case Name: Rupa Ashok Hurra Vs. Ashok Hurra
Issue Presented: Whether the Supreme Court can revisit its own final judgment in cases of gross miscarriage of justice.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner sought a reconsideration of a Supreme Court judgment after exhausting review petitions.
Ruling by Lower Court: Review petition was dismissed.
Argument: Petitioner argued for a judicial remedy in rare cases where fundamental rights are violated even after a final judgment.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 137; Supreme Court Rules.
Rules: Principle of finality of judgments; exceptions in case of denial of natural justice.
Precedent: Previous cases on judicial finality.
Ratio of the Decision: Curative petitions are permissible only in rare and exceptional circumstances to prevent grave injustice.
Ruling: Supreme Court created the concept of curative petitions for exceptional cases.

Case Name: Shyam Narayan Chouksey Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Compulsory playing of the national anthem in cinemas violates constitutional freedoms.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought mandatory playing of the national anthem before films to foster national pride.
Ruling by Lower Court: No binding direction issued by lower courts.
Argument: Petitioner contended that playing the national anthem promotes national unity and respect.
Statute: Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971.
Rules: Constitutional duty under Article 51A(a) to respect national symbols.
Precedent: Earlier rulings on symbolic expressions and limits of state-mandated patriotism.
Ratio of the Decision: Respect for the anthem is essential, but mandating it in specific settings must not infringe individual freedoms.
Ruling: Supreme Court initially made playing the national anthem mandatory but made it optional pending government guidelines.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N.M. Thomas
Issue Presented: Whether reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Facts of the Case: Kerala government provided promotional benefits to SC/ST employees; challenged as unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: Kerala High Court struck down the reservation in promotions policy.
Argument: State argued that social justice measures must extend to promotions for backward classes.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 16(4), enabling reservation in appointments and promotions.
Rules: Interpretation of Article 16(4) and its scope in public employment and promotions.
Precedent: Earlier decisions excluding promotions were reinterpreted in light of evolving jurisprudence.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservation in promotions is permissible if aimed at ensuring adequate representation.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld reservation in promotions, recognizing it as a tool for substantive equality.

Case Name: Vishwanath Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Dowry death and burden of proof under Section 304B IPC.
Facts of the Case: The deceased died within 7 years of marriage under unnatural circumstances with dowry allegations.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court convicted the accused relying on circumstantial evidence.
Argument: Petitioner argued that presumption should not override the requirement of proof.
Statute: IPC Section 304B, Section 113B of the Evidence Act, Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961.
Rules: Previous cases on dowry death and burden of proof.
Precedent: Cases like Kans Raj v. State of Punjab clarifying the evidentiary standard.
Ratio of the Decision: In dowry death cases, burden shifts to the accused to disprove presumption of guilt.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the conviction, stressing careful application of presumptive burden.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Ganga Pollution Case)
Issue Presented: Whether failure to control industrial discharge.
Facts of the Case: Industries were discharging untreated effluents into the Ganga.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court gave directions to control pollution but lacked strict enforcement.
Argument: Petitioner contended that environmental degradation infringed the constitutional right to life and health.
Rules: Principles of sustainable development, polluter pays, and precautionary principle.
Precedent: Ratlam Municipality, Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum, and earlier MC Mehta cases.
Ratio of the Decision: State has a constitutional duty to protect natural resources.
Ruling: Supreme Court directed closure of non-compliant tanneries.

Case Name: Govind Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether surveillance under M.P. Police Regulation 855 violates the right to privacy under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, categorized as a habitual offender, was subjected to surveillance, he argued that it infringed on his right to privacy and liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the constitutionality of the surveillance for law enforcement needs.
Argument: Petitioner contended that constant police monitoring violated.
Statute: Article 21, Constitution of India; M.P. Police Regulation 855.
Rules: Any restriction on privacy must be legal, necessary, and proportionate.
Precedent: Kharak Singh v. State of U.P., R.C. Cooper v. Union of India.
Ratio of the Decision: Right to privacy is implicit and may be restricted only through just, fair, and reasonable law.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld Regulation but mandated strict procedural safeguards to prevent misuse.

Case Name: Indian Medical Association Vs. V.P. Shantha
Issue Presented: Whether medical services fall under “service” in the Consumer Protection Act.
Facts of the Case: Respondent alleged negligence; petitioner claimed CPA doesn’t apply to medical professionals.
Ruling by Lower Court: Held medical services for consideration are covered by CPA.
Argument: Petitioner argued doctor-patient ties are fiduciary, not commercial.
Rules: Services provided for a fee qualify under consumer law.
Precedent: No major precedent; first significant interpretation.
Ratio of the Decision: Paid medical services fall under CPA; free charitable services do not.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld CPA applicability for paid medical services.

Case Name: Peopleâ€™s Union for Democratic Rights Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether state failure to enforce labor laws violates fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner highlighted use of bonded labor and underpayment in state-funded Asiad construction.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found violations but stopped short of mandatory enforcement.
Argument: Non-compliance with labor laws violates rights to life, dignity, and freedom from exploitation.
Rules: State is constitutionally bound to ensure statutory labor protections.
Precedent: Relied on judicial activism and expanding Article 21 protections.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights are violated if state fails to enforce labor protections in public projects.
Ruling: Supreme Court mandated labor law compliance.

Case Name: Ramesh Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether a TV serial for allegedly spreading communal disharmony.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner argued the serial incited hatred and promoted communal disharmony.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled the serial could be aired, citing no clear evidence of incitement to violence.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the serial violated public order by fostering religious intolerance.
Rules: Freedom of speech is subject to reasonable restrictions for public order.
Precedent: Precedents on media regulation, religious intolerance.
Ratio of the Decision: Artistic freedom is protected, but must not harm public peace or religious harmony.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the broadcast, subject to monitoring for objectionable content.

Case Name: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. Vs. State of Rajasthan and Others
Issue Presented: Whether freight charges should be included in the taxable sale price under the Central Sales Tax Act.
Facts of the Case: The authorities considered freight as part of the sale price, which made it taxable.
Ruling by Lower Court: Lower authorities ruled that freight charges were part of the sale price and subject to sales tax.
Argument: Petitioner contended that freight charges are separate from the sale price and should be excluded from the taxable amount.
Statute: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, 1954.
Rules: Freight charges are not part of the taxable sale price under the Central Sales Tax Act.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the taxation of freight in commodity sales under controlled pricing schemes.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court's ruling would determine whether freight charges could be taxed as part of the sale price under the Sales Tax Act.
Ruling: The decision is awaited on whether freight charges should be included in the taxable sale price.

Case Name: R.G. Anand Vs. Delux Films
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent’s film infringes on the petitioner’s copyright in his play due to similarities in theme and expression.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner claimed that substantial similarities between the play and film constituted copyright infringement.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that similarities were coincidental and not ruled against copyright infringement.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the film copied substantial elements of the play, violating copyright.
Rules: Copyright protection does not extend to broad ideas or themes.
Precedent: Previous cases on artistic originality and the test for substantial similarity.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that copyright only protects the expression of ideas.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s decision, ruling that broad themes or ideas are not protected by copyright.

Case Name: Shri Roshanlal Gautam Vs. State Of Uttar Pradesh And Others
Respondent: State of Uttar Pradesh and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the Uttar Pradesh government's action to nationalize transport routes.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s contract carriage permit was revoked due to the nationalization of transport services.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the State’s right to nationalize transport services.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the government’s decision to nationalize routes violated his rights under the contract.
Rules: Extent of State’s authority to nationalize transport routes.
Precedent: Cases on the validity of nationalization of transport services under the Motor Vehicles Act.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that the State has the authority to nationalize routes and revoke private permits.
Ruling: Supreme Court's decision pending.

Case Name: P. Rathinam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the criminalizes attempted suicide, violates the right to life and dignity.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that criminalizing attempted suicide infringed on personal autonomy and violated the right to life.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Section 309 IPC, affirming that it did not violate the Constitution.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the punishment for attempted suicide violates the fundamental right.
Rules: The case examines whether punishing attempted suicide is inconsistent with the right to life.
Precedent: Precedents regarding the balance between personal autonomy and state intervention in the right to life.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court initially struck, affirming that it is not in violation of the right to life.
Ruling: Supreme Court initially struck down Section 309 IPC but later upheld its validity in Gian Kaur case.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the central government’s allocation of funds to Karnataka.
Facts of the Case: The state of Karnataka argued that the central government's allocation unfairly curtailed its financial rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the central government, dismissing Karnataka's challenge.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the financial allocation methods were inequitable.
Rules: Financial allocations must be equitable.
Precedent: Previous cases on the allocation of finances between the state and central governments under federalism.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court upheld the central government's financial distribution policy.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the policy of the central government while suggesting improvements for more equitable financial allocation.

Case Name: Rajbala Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether the imposition of educational qualifications for contesting local body elections.
Facts of the Case: The amendment to Haryana's Panchayati Raj Act requiring educational qualifications for local body elections was contested as discriminatory.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the amendment, declaring it constitutional.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the educational qualifications imposed were discriminatory and violated the right to equality.
Rules: The law does not violate Article 14.
Precedent: Cases discussing restrictions on electoral participation.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court upheld the law, stating that reasonable restrictions on qualifications are constitutionally valid.
Ruling: Supreme Court affirmed the constitutionality of the educational qualification requirement.

Case Name: Municipal Board, Manglaur Vs. Sri Mahadeoji Maharaj
Issue Presented: Whether the vacant land adjacent to a public road belonged to the Municipality or was private property.
Facts of the Case: The Municipality planned development on vacant land adjacent to a road.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court granted possession of the land to the plaintiff, ruling the land was private property.
Argument: Land was private property, and the Municipality had no right to it.
Statute: Municipal governance laws and property rights related to public roads.
Rules: Ownership of land adjacent to public roads and the rights of private property owners.
Precedent: Case law concerning municipal authority over roads and adjoining lands.
Ratio of the Decision: The vacant land adjacent to the road was private or public property.
Ruling: Awaiting final decision.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. Association for Democratic Reforms
Issue Presented: Whether candidates should be required to disclose criminal records, assets, and liabilities.
Facts of the Case: A PIL demanded that candidates disclose their criminal background and financial details to voters.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of mandatory disclosure for informed voting.
Argument: Respondent argued that disclosure was necessary to ensure voters could make informed decisions.
Rules: Voter rights to transparency and electoral fairness.
Precedent: Earlier cases on electoral transparency and the right to information for voters.
Ratio of the Decision: Disclosure of candidates' criminal records and financial details.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that candidates must disclose their criminal records and financial details.

Case Name: Jindal Stainless Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether the imposition of entry tax by states violates the right to free trade between states.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contested the state’s right to impose entry tax, claiming it restricted interstate commerce.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the imposition of entry tax, ruling it was within state powers.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the entry tax impeded free trade and was unconstitutional.
Rules: States can regulate trade but must not hinder the free flow of commerce between states.
Precedent: Earlier cases interpreting the balance between state taxation powers and free trade.
Ratio of the Decision: Entry tax can be imposed by states if it does not impede the free flow of interstate trade.
Ruling: Supreme Court validated the entry tax, reinforcing the state’s power to regulate trade.

Case Name: M/S Japan Airlines Co. Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Respondent: Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Issue Presented: Whether airport landing and parking fees should be categorized as rent under the Income Tax Act for TDS purposes.
Facts of the Case: The Airlines paid airport charges for runway maintenance, and the issue arose whether TDS applies under rent provisions.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Income Tax Department ruled that these payments constitute rent, hence TDS is applicable.
Argument: Petitioner argued that these were payments for services and should not be treated as rent.
Statute: Section 194-I of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
Rules: Whether airport charges for services like landing and parking fall under rent as per Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Previous cases on the taxation of services vs. rent, specifically in the context of aviation services.
Ratio of the Decision: Payments for airport-related services are classified as rent for TDS of the Income Tax Act.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court’s decision.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Jagjit Singh
Issue Presented: Whether temporary employees are entitled to equal work for permanent employees.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued for equal pay as he performed similar duties to permanent employees.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that temporary employees doing similar work to permanent employees.
Argument: Petitioner contended that equal pay should be given if duties performed are the same.
Rules: Equal pay for equal work as a constitutional principle.
Precedent: Previous rulings reinforcing equal pay for equal work for temporary employees.
Ratio of the Decision: Temporary employees performing the same work as permanent employees are entitled to equal pay.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Court's ruling and reinforced the principle of equal pay for equal work.

Case Name: Kailas & Others Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Whether honor killings should be treated as separate offenses.
Facts of the Case: The petitioners were convicted for murdering a couple in the name of honor, challenging the charges and sentencing.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the conviction under murder charges.
Argument: Petitioners argued that honor customs should influence sentencing, despite the gravity of the crime.
Rules: Rules regarding murder and aggravating factors like honor killings.
Precedent: Precedent cases on honor killings, emphasizing the severity of the crime.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court upheld that honor killings are severe crimes and must be punished.
Ruling: Supreme Court reinforced the importance of treating honor killings as murder with stringent punishment.

Case Name: Krishna Pillai Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Whether the confession of guilt in a gold smuggling case is sufficient for conviction under the Land Customs Act.
Facts of the Case: The accused, Krishna Pillai, was caught smuggling gold and later confessed.
Ruling by Lower Court: Trial Court convicted the petitioner based on the smuggling and the confession.
Argument: The defense argued that the confession was not obtained properly.
Statute: Section 7(1)(b) of the Land Customs Act, 1924.
Rules: Confessions should be voluntary and not coerced for admissibility in court.
Precedent: Precedents regarding the weight of confessions in smuggling cases.
Ratio of the Decision: Confessions are valid, but their admissibility must meet due process requirements.
Ruling: High Court upheld the conviction but ruled that the gold should not be confiscated due to procedural issues.

Case Name: State of Rajasthan Vs. Jagannath
Issue Presented: Whether illegal encroachment of government land can lead to eviction without proper rehabilitation.
Facts of the Case: The respondent illegally occupied government land, challenging eviction without rehabilitation provisions.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ordered eviction without considering the rehabilitation of the respondent.
Argument: The defense argued that eviction should be conditioned upon providing rehabilitation.
Rules: Policies requiring rehabilitation for evicted individuals.
Precedent: Cases focusing on the balance between eviction and rehabilitation for encroachers.
Ratio of the Decision: Encroachment must be removed, but the state must consider rehabilitation.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the eviction order but emphasized that rehabilitation should be provided.

Case Name: National Legal Services Authority Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether transgender individuals should be legally recognized as a third gender with full rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that transgender people should be recognized as a third gender and provided equal rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled recognizing the rights of transgender.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the denial of legal recognition and rights to transgender people violated fundamental rights.
Statute: Articles 14, 15, and 21 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: The application of fundamental rights to marginalized gender identities.
Precedent: Previous cases on equality, dignity, and the rights of minority groups.
Ratio of the Decision: Recognition of transgender individuals as the third gender is necessary for ensuring equal rights.
Ruling: Supreme Court granted transgender individuals legal recognition as a third gender.

Case Name: Mithu Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory death penalty under Section 303 IPC violates the right to life.
