Facts of the Case: Petitioner argued that the mandatory death penalty for life prisoners violates fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the mandatory death penalty provision as constitutionally valid.
Argument: Petitioner contended that mandatory death penalties violate the Constitution.
Rules: Judicial discretion in sentencing and the fundamental right to life.
Precedent: Previous cases on the constitutionality of mandatory death sentences.
Ratio of the Decision: Mandatory death penalty is unconstitutional as it eliminates judicial discretion and violates the right to life.
Ruling: Supreme Court struck down Section 303 IPC, ruling that the mandatory death penalty violates the Constitution.

Case Name: D.K. Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether guidelines are needed to protect against custodial violence and abuse.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed highlighting cases of custodial torture and excessive use of police force.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court recommended procedural reforms, but no binding guidelines were issued.
Argument: Petitioner argued for the establishment of firm guidelines to prevent custodial violence.
Rules: Guidelines for police conduct during detention and arrest.
Precedent: Previous cases on custodial violence and constitutional protections.
Ratio of the Decision: Custodial violence must be prevented by issuing strict procedural guidelines.
Ruling: Supreme Court issued binding  guidelines for arrest and custodial treatment.

Case Name: Ajay Hasia Vs. Khalid Mujib Sehravardi
Issue Presented: Whether a government-funded institution is considered a 'State' under Article 12 of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: A public technical institution was accused of discriminatory practices, leading to a question of its status.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled the institution was not considered 'State'.
Argument: Petitioner argued that government funding and control make the institution an entity bound.
Rules: Interpretation of 'State' in relation to government funding and control.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the application of fundamental rights to public institutions.
Ratio of the Decision: Government-funded and controlled institutions are considered 'State'.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that the institution was indeed covered under Article 12 and must adhere to fundamental rights.

Case Name: Narmada Bachao Andolan Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the construction of the Sardar Sarovar Dam violates environmental and rehabilitation policies.
Facts of the Case: The petition raised concerns about the ecological harm and displacement caused by the Sardar Sarovar Dam project.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the dam’s construction, focusing on its developmental benefits.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the construction violated environmental safeguards.
Statute: Environmental Protection Act, 1986; Resettlement and Rehabilitation Guidelines.
Rules: Environmental protection and rehabilitation measures under law.
Precedent: Previous rulings on developmental projects and environmental law.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court emphasized the need for balancing development with ecological protection.
Ruling: Supreme Court allowed the project but required strict adherence to rehabilitation and environmental safeguards.

Case Name: The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Vs. S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Respondent: S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether remittances made by an agent under an agreement are taxable income.
Facts of the Case: The company was an agent for foreign corporations and sold goods on their behalf.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held that S. K. F. acted as an agent and that remittances were taxable only after the sales proceeds were realized.
Argument: S. K. F. argued that remittances were not taxable as they were merely transfers of funds, not profits.
Statute: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-Tax Act.
Rules: Remittances made under contractual obligation were not considered taxable income.
Precedent: Previous cases interpreting the taxation of agent-related remittances.
Ratio of the Decision: The timing of remittances impacts taxable income, and remittances under contractual obligations.
Ruling: Supreme Court held that the remittances, being contractual transfers, were not taxable as income for S.K.F.

Case Name: Turner Morrison And Co., Ltd Vs. Hungerford Investment Trust Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether the claim for reimbursement of super tax payments and interest is legally justified.
Facts of the Case: Turner Morrison claimed it was entitled to reimbursement of super tax payments and interest from Hungerford.
Ruling by Lower Court: The claim was dismissed due to lack of sufficient proof and barred by waiver and limitation.
Argument: Turner Morrison argued it was entitled to recover voluntary payments of super tax and interest.
Statute: Contract law principles, waiver, estoppel, and taxation.
Rules: Claims that are voluntarily made and barred by limitation cannot be enforced under contract or taxation law.
Precedent: Previous cases involving waiver, estoppel, and limitation in claims for reimbursement.
Ratio of the Decision: Claims for reimbursement and interest must be based on a legal obligation.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the dismissal.

Case Name: M/S. Corporate Ispat Alloys Limited Vs. M/S. Jayaswal Neco Industries Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the winding-up petition should proceed despite ongoing arbitration.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner claimed that arbitration proceedings should not halt winding-up proceedings.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court postponed the decision on winding-up due to the ongoing arbitration process.
Argument: Arbitration should not delay the winding-up petition decision.
Rules: Judicial authority on insolvency can’t be postponed because of arbitration.
Precedent: Cases where winding-up proceedings were considered despite arbitration.
Ratio of the Decision: Arbitration does not prevent the Company Court from determining insolvency independently.
Ruling: Supreme Court emphasized that winding-up petitions must be considered independently from arbitration.

Case Name: National Organic Chemical Inds. Ltd Vs. Miheer H. Mafatlal
Issue Presented: Whether the Company Court exceeded its jurisdiction by addressing shareholder title disputes in a merger case.
Facts of the Case: The Company Court ruled on the validity of share allotment despite a City Civil Court's injunction.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court ruled share allotment invalid, overstepping its jurisdiction regarding share ownership.
Argument: Company Court erred by deciding on share ownership and validity within merger proceedings.
Rules: Share ownership disputes should be resolved separately from merger proceedings under statutory rules.
Precedent: Court rulings against company courts addressing share ownership in corporate restructuring.
Ratio of the Decision: Company Courts should avoid making decisions on share ownership validity during mergers or restructuring.
Ruling: Supreme Court ruled that share ownership issues must be dealt with through separate statutory procedures.

Case Name: Anjuman Islamia and Others Vs. Munshi Tegh Ali and Others
Issue Presented: Dispute over the ownership of Badi Takia and whether it had been dedicated as wakf property.
Facts of the Case: The plaintiffs claimed the property was privately owned, while the defendants asserted it was wakf.
Ruling by Lower Court: Trial Court upheld the plaintiffs’ ownership and dismissed the wakf claim by the defendants.
Argument: Plaintiffs argued that no formal dedication of the property had occurred, thus it remained their private land.
Statute: Property law and legal standards for establishing wakf dedication.
Rules: Mere religious use does not establish wakf ownership without formal dedication.
Precedent: Court decisions asserting that religious use alone does not justify wakf claims.
Ratio of the Decision: Affirmed that the property remained privately owned due to lack of formal wakf dedication.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the trial court’s decision, reinforcing the need for formal evidence in wakf claims.

Case Name: Hindustan Petroleum Corpn. Ltd Vs. Ashok Ranghba Ambre
Issue Presented: Dispute over whether an ad hoc employee can be converted to permanent status after prolonged service.
Facts of the Case: The respondent worked in a casual position for a long period and sought conversion to permanent status.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Labour Court ruled in favor of the respondent, granting them permanent status. The High Court upheld this ruling.
Argument: HPCL contended that long-term ad hoc workers do not automatically qualify for permanent employment.
Statute: Labour law governing employment status and recruitment processes.
Rules: Formal recruitment procedures are mandatory for granting permanent employment status.
Precedent: Previous cases on casual worker conversion to permanent status based on formal hiring processes.
Ratio of the Decision: Permanent employment status requires a formal recruitment process and adherence to regulations.
Ruling: The Supreme Court clarified that employment without a formal contract does not confer permanent status.

Case Name: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another Vs. State of Gujarat and Others
Petitioner: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant's land could be exempted from acquisition as it was critical for their industrial operations.
Facts of the Case: The appellant’s land, needed for its textile mills, was part of an industrial acquisition project and the appellant sought exemption.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the appellant’s land was part of the broader industrial acquisition.
Argument: The appellant sought exemption from acquisition due to its necessity for the textile mills’ operations.
Statute: Gujarat Industrial Development Act, 1962 and relevant constitutional provisions.
Rules: Land required for a public purpose, like industrial development, cannot be exempted based on private use claims.
Precedent: Rulings affirming that land designated for public purposes cannot be exempted for private use.
Ratio of the Decision: Land that is deemed necessary for public purpose under the industrial development law cannot be excluded.
Ruling: Rejecting the appellant’s request for exemption.

Case Name: Pratima Chowdhury Vs. Kalpana Mukherjee
Issue Presented: Dispute over the legality of the property transfer process conducted by the Society and Registrar.
Facts of the Case: She transferred ownership to Pratima Chowdhury with proper channels.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court upheld the validity of the property transfer to Pratima Chowdhury, affirming compliance.
Argument: Kalpana Mukherjee challenged the transfer’s validity, questioning whether it met the legal criteria.
Statute: Co-operative Societies Act and relevant housing society rules.
Rules: Transfers in co-operative societies must follow formal procedures.
Precedent: Legal precedents affirm that a valid society resolution and Registrar's approval make a transfer binding.
Ratio of the Decision: A transfer following society and registrar approval is legally binding.
Ruling: The transfer was upheld, and Pratima Chowdhury was recognized as the rightful owner under the law.

Case Name: P.P. Enterprises Etc. Vs. Union of India and Others Etc.
Issue Presented: Dispute over the justification for government-imposed limits on sugar storage.
Facts of the Case: The government issued storage limits for sugar, which were challenged by dealers outside Calcutta for being unfair.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court ruled that the restrictions were regulatory in nature and constitutionally valid.
Argument: The government justified the classification based on regional economic needs and public interest.
Statute: Directive Principles of State Policy, which allow for state-imposed economic regulations in public interest.
Rules: Economic regulations should be proportional and reasonable to meet public objectives.
Precedent: Precedents confirm that regulations impacting economic activities must align with public interest.
Ratio of the Decision: The classification and storage limits were constitutionally valid.
Ruling: The regulation was upheld as being reasonable, regulatory, and justified under public interest.

Case Name: Ashok Kumar Barik Vs. State of Orissa
Issue Presented: Challenge to conviction under Section 302 IPC, questioning if guilt was proven beyond reasonable doubt.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was convicted for the murder of the deceased, based on witness testimonies and medical evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court acquitted the petitioner after raising doubts about the evidence and prosecution's case.
Argument: The petitioner challenged the reliability of key witness testimonies and disputed the sufficiency of the evidence.
Rules: Evidence must be conclusive, and circumstantial evidence must lead to a single inference of guilt.
Precedent: Case law emphasizes that circumstantial evidence must not leave room for alternative hypotheses.
Ratio of the Decision: The acquittal was granted due to doubts about the prosecution's evidence and witness credibility.
Ruling: The conviction was overturned by the High Court, which found the prosecution's case insufficient to establish guilt.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. The Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the Board’s smuggling order against the petitioner followed due process and had sufficient evidence.
Facts of the Case: The Board claimed Kartar Singh was linked to smuggling, but failed to establish direct evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower authorities upheld the smuggling allegations based on suspicion and indirect evidence.
Argument: Kartar Singh argued the order was based on assumptions, not proof, and failed procedural requirements.
Rules: Orders affecting rights must be based on clear evidence and adhere strictly to procedural fairness.
Precedent: Judicial rulings emphasize due process and bar conviction on speculative or inferential grounds.
Ratio of the Decision: Administrative findings based on assumptions and without due process are not sustainable in law.
Ruling: The order was quashed, and Kartar Singh was acquitted as the Board failed to meet legal and procedural standards.

Case Name: Surya Kant Roy Vs. Imamul Hai Khan
Issue Presented: Whether holding a position on the Mines Board of Health disqualified the respondent and influenced the election.
Facts of the Case: The respondent was a member of the Mines Board of Health, partially funded by the government.
Ruling by Lower Court: Petition was dismissed as no conclusive proof of disqualification or electoral misconduct was shown.
Argument: The petitioner argued the Board post constituted an office of profit due to government control.
Statute: Representation of the People Act; Election Disqualification Provisions.
Rules: Disqualification requires actual benefit and government control; electoral fraud requires direct evidence.
Precedent: Past rulings stress direct impact and substantial benefit to invoke disqualification.
Ratio of the Decision: No substantial benefit or government control proven; electoral integrity not compromised.
Ruling: Election result upheld; respondent not disqualified.

Case Name: Punjab Traders And Ors Vs. State Of Punjab And Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the Amendment Act violated or imposed unconstitutional trade restrictions.
Facts of the Case: Traders challenged the amendment alleging it introduced unjust trade controls.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court found no discriminatory impact or violation of fundamental rights.
Argument: Petitioners argued the amendment unfairly regulated their trade in violation.
Statute: Constitution of India – Article 14 and trade regulation statutes.
Rules: Equal protection claims must show actual discriminatory or arbitrary treatment.
Precedent: Precedents show general amendments are upheld unless specific unequal treatment is shown.
Ratio of the Decision: No evidence of discrimination or arbitrariness.
Ruling: Dismissed; no violation of Article 14 found.

Case Name: Reena Suresh Alhat Vs. State Of Maharashtra And Anr
Issue Presented: Whether dismissal of the writ petition violated the petitioner's electoral rights.
Facts of the Case: High Court refused to entertain the writ petition, citing availability of election petition.
Ruling by Lower Court: Held that post-election remedies were adequate; declined to examine the petition on merits.
Argument: Petitioner's fundamental right to free and fair elections was denied judicial review.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 329(b); judicial review under Article 226.
Rules: Writs cannot challenge elections directly if election petition remedy exists.
Precedent: Courts have held that only in rare exceptions can writs bypass election process.
Ratio of the Decision: Supreme Court admitted the appeal to examine whether denial of writ infringed on electoral fairness.
Ruling: Supreme Court agreed to hear the matter in light of potential electoral rights violation.

Case Name: Karimbil Kunhikoman Vs. State Of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether differential land compensation based on property value violates equality and fairness.
Facts of the Case: Kerala imposed progressive deductions from compensation depending on land value tiers.
Ruling by Lower Court: Lower court upheld the state's compensation scheme, reasoning that wealthier owners could bear larger cuts.
Argument: Petitioner claimed the scheme arbitrarily penalized owners of high-value land.
Statute: Land Acquisition Act; Constitutional Right to Equality.
Rules: Equal compensation for similar property loss is a constitutional mandate.
Precedent: Courts have ruled that fairness cannot be overridden by arbitrary classifications in compensation.
Ratio of the Decision: Compensation must reflect parity and fairness; tiered deduction was struck down as unjust.
Ruling: Held that tiered compensation violated principles of just and equal treatment.

Case Name: Moideenkutty Haji Vs. Director General & Others
Issue Presented: Whether temporary roof additions in a heritage zone constitute unauthorized construction.
Facts of the Case: Petitioner constructed an aluminium roof on a heritage structure without prior approval.
Ruling by Lower Court: Found that the construction violated heritage regulations and lacked required permissions.
Argument: Claimed it was a minor addition to preserve the structure, not an unauthorized modification.
Statute: Urban heritage and coastal regulation zoning acts.
Rules: All structural changes in protected zones must be pre-approved under applicable laws.
Precedent: Judicial precedent holds that even protective modifications need statutory approvals.
Ratio of the Decision: Good intention does not exempt one from following conservation laws permissions are mandatory.
Ruling: Affirmed removal of the unauthorised addition.

Case Name: S. S. Shetty Vs. Bharat Nidhi, Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether pension and gratuity must be considered in compensation upon reinstatement.
Facts of the Case: RBI had sanctioned bye-laws including pension and gratuity; the petitioner sought full reinstatement benefits.
Ruling by Lower Court: Tribunal granted reinstatement with benefits, referencing statutory terms.
Argument: Argued that compensation must reflect full service benefits.
Statute: Industrial Disputes Act; applicable pension/gratuity regulations.
Rules: Financial compensation must reflect statutory benefits upon reinstatement.
Precedent: Reinstatement jurisprudence supports inclusion of benefits unless explicitly waived.
Ratio of the Decision: Compensation must mirror statutory entitlements, reinforcing fairness in reinstatement.
Ruling: Judgment confirmed reinstatement along with computation of full benefits owed under service terms.

Case Name: Essco Fabs Pvt. Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether private industrial expansion qualifies as 'public purpose' under land acquisition law.
Facts of the Case: Essco applied for acquisition to expand its export unit. Govt rejected saying it didn’t serve public need.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against Essco, citing lack of public purpose under law.
Argument: Essco asserted that export-led industrial growth contributes to national interest.
Rules: Land acquisition must strictly serve defined public interest, not private enterprise.
Precedent: Courts have rejected land acquisition for purely private expansion in absence of broader social benefit.
Ratio of the Decision: Public purpose' must involve direct public benefit, not indirect economic contribution by private units.
Ruling: Court dismissed Essco’s claim.

Case Name: Pankaj Kumar Vs. State of Jharkhand & Ors.
Issue Presented: Whether denial of reservation benefits after state reorganization violated service continuity guarantees.
Facts of the Case: Absorbed into Jharkhand services after Bihar’s bifurcation, petitioner lost reservation status.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled against the petitioner, citing non-transferability of Bihar’s reservation benefits.
Argument: Petitioner argued that administrative reorganization cannot nullify pre-existing service entitlements.
Rules: State bifurcation cannot impair previously granted employment conditions.
Precedent: Similar rulings emphasized preservation of pre-existing rights after state reorganization.
Ratio of the Decision: Employees transferred post-bifurcation must retain their original service protections.
Ruling: Supreme Court restored benefits, ensuring protection under the Act.

Case Name: K. Gopinathan Nair and Others Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether purchases through CCI constituted sales in the course of import under tax exemption law.
Facts of the Case: Assessees claimed exemption since purchases were linked to imports arranged through CCI.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court held that the purchases were not exempt and were post-import domestic transactions.
Argument: Petitioners argued sales were inseparable from the import chain, deserving exemption.
Statute: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956; Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963
Rules: Only sales involving direct import contracts are exempt under Section 5(2) of CST Act.
Precedent: Prior rulings deny exemption where goods are sold after import without direct foreign contracts.
Ratio of the Decision: Purchases lacking a direct nexus to foreign contracts cannot claim import exemption.
Ruling: Appeals dismissed.

Case Name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner must make further payments for market fees despite partial payments already made.
Facts of the Case: The appellant had made part payments of market fees and sought refunds for prior payments.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court affirmed the validity of the previous assessments and upheld the liability for further payments.
Argument: The petitioner requested refunds for prior payments and opposed further recovery based on previous decisions.
Statute: Bihar Market Fee Act, 1961 (Section 27-B); Constitutional provisions (Articles 226, 142).
Rules: Prior payments cannot be refunded unless new grounds are established.
Precedent: The Belsund Sugar Mills ruling guided the court's decision regarding market fee recovery.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court reaffirmed that payments once made cannot be reversed, and the appellant was liable for further payments.
Ruling: The appeals were dismissed.

Case Name: P.C. Sethi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the administrative instructions regarding seniority for temporary assistants are valid.
Facts of the Case: The dispute revolved around whether temporary assistants were entitled to seniority based on the 1971 memorandum.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the seniority rules, stating that they were valid and applicable to temporary assistants.
Argument: The government argued that seniority must follow structured absorption rules and cannot be claimed without meeting conditions.
Rules: Seniority rules for temporary assistants must align with the structured process of absorption.
Precedent: Judicial precedents established that seniority cannot be claimed.
Ratio of the Decision: The government’s seniority rules are constitutionally valid.
Ruling: The court upheld the seniority rules and rejected the petitioner’s claim.

Case Name: Ruchi Majoo Vs. Sanjeev Majoo
Issue Presented: Whether the father should be granted visitation and overnight custody of the child during vacations.
Facts of the Case: The respondent sought visitation rights and overnight custody during vacations.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court allowed visitation rights but did not specifically rule on overnight custody.
Argument: The respondent argued that his relationship with the child was being restricted unfairly and sought more visitation time.
Statute: Guardian and Wards Act, Family Law.
Rules: The court focused on ensuring the non-custodial parent has fair visitation.
Precedent: Past judgments reiterate that non-custodial parents should not be denied fair visitation rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Visitation rights must be provided to the father, ensuring the child’s relationship.
Ruling: The father was granted visitation rights, with an emphasis on maintaining his relationship.

Case Name: Charanjit Pal Jindal Vs. M/s. L.N. Metalics
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant’s conviction for dishonored cheques should stand considering the delayed payments and commitments.
Facts of the Case: The appellant had failed to clear outstanding dues despite written requests.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Trial Court convicted the appellant for issuing dishonored cheques.
Argument: The appellant maintained that circumstances led to delayed payments and that he did not willfully default.
Statute: Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
Rules: A dishonored cheque due to lack of funds is sufficient for criminal liability under Section 138.
Precedent: Legal precedents confirms that issuing cheques without funds can result in legal action under Section 138.
Ratio of the Decision: The issuance of dishonored cheques due to insufficient funds is sufficient grounds for criminal conviction.
Ruling: The High Court upheld the Trial Court’s ruling, affirming the appellant’s conviction for dishonored cheques.

Case Name: State of Haryana Vs. Northern Indian Glass Industries Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the land resumption process by the State of Haryana followed principles of natural justice and legal requirements.
Facts of the Case: The case concerns a dispute over land resumption by the State of Haryana for industrial non-compliance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Collector upheld the compensation amount from 1974 and sided with the State in the resumption matter.
Argument: The State contended that the land resumption was in compliance with legal procedures, arguing procedural fairness was maintained.
Rules: The State’s duty to follow procedural fairness in land resumption was emphasized under the Land Acquisition Act.
Precedent: The case reinforced precedents requiring procedural compliance in land resumption.
Ratio of the Decision: The High Court emphasized that the resumption of land without proper legal procedure is unlawful.
Ruling: The High Court ruled in favor of ensuring procedural fairness and upheld the decision against the State's appeal.

Case Name: Ms. Sarita Singh Vs. M/s Shree Infosoft Private Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner was legally on deputation and the legal consequences of such a status.
Facts of the Case: The case revolves around the dispute over whether the petitioner was sent on deputation.
Ruling by Lower Court: Not specified
Argument: The petitioner contested the deputation claim, arguing that without formal documentation or consent.
Rules: The legal definition of deputation was considered, emphasizing formal communication and employee consent.
Precedent: The case of State of Punjab v. Inder Singh was cited to clarify that deputation involves explicit documentation and agreement.
Ratio of the Decision: The court emphasized that deputation involves a formal agreement between employer and employee.
Ruling: The court ruled that the petitioner was not on deputation as there was no explicit agreement.

Case Name: Parmanand Patel (D) Th. Lrs. Vs. Sudha A. Chowgule
Petitioner: Legal representatives of late Parmanand Patel
Issue Presented: Whether multiple sets of documents concerning property division were legally valid and free from coercion.
Facts of the Case: The dispute involves the validity of multiple documents regarding the division of property.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that the documents executed by the petitioners in favor of Sudha were valid and legally binding.
Argument: The petitioners contended that coercion affected the execution of the second set of documents and sought their invalidation.
Statute: Indian Contract Act, Evidence Act, Succession Laws.
Rules: The execution of property division documents must meet legal standards for fairness and voluntariness.
Precedent: Judicial precedents highlight the need to examine the execution process to confirm it was voluntary.
Ratio of the Decision: The case focused on whether the second set of documents was executed fairly without undue influence or coercion.
Ruling: The High Court maintained Sudha’s rights based on the valid documents, but recognized concerns about procedural irregularities.

Case Name: Patel Ahmed Mohammad Vs. Balwant Singh Rajput
Issue Presented: Whether the election of Patel Ahmed Mohammad was marred by corrupt practices.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the election due to allegations of electoral malpractice, bribery, and procedural errors.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court allowed the election petition to proceed, dismissing preliminary objections for summary dismissal.
Argument: The petition raised concerns about the influence of bribery and procedural errors during vote counting, necessitating a review.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1951; Indian Election Laws.
Rules: The focus was on evaluating the petition based on substantive corruption allegations, not just procedural issues.
Precedent: The ruling emphasized that procedural irregularities alone cannot justify dismissing an election petition.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court ruled that the case should proceed to trial, as it was based on substantial allegations of corruption, not procedural flaws.
Ruling: The High Court dismissed preliminary objections and allowed the election petition to go forward for trial.

Case Name: Podar Mills Limited Vs. State Bank of India
Issue Presented: Whether the court's discretion in appointing a receiver over the assets of Podar Mills was exercised correctly.
Facts of the Case: The dispute arose from Podar Mills defaulting on loan payments, prompting the appointment of a receiver.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that appointing a receiver was necessary to protect creditor interests.
Argument: Podar Mills argued that the existing management by the Custodian made a receiver unnecessary and potentially harmful.
Statute: Transfer of Property Act, 1882; Indian Contract Act.
Rules: The focus was on the role of judicial discretion in appointing receivers in cases involving financial mismanagement.
Precedent: Judicial precedents indicate that when creditors' interests are threatened, a receiver can be appointed to safeguard assets.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling upheld the decision to appoint a receiver, emphasizing that creditor protection takes precedence.
Ruling: The court upheld the appointment of the receiver to protect the interests of the State Bank of India.

Case Name: The Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. Shri D. K. Worlikar
Issue Presented: Whether the Tribunal correctly interpreted the scope of the notification under the Industrial Disputes Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the notification applied solely to sugar manufacturing and its by-products.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Labour Court supported the petitioner’s interpretation, narrowing the scope of the notification.
Argument: The respondent argued that the notification should be construed as applying broadly across industries.
Rules: The case focused on the appropriate scope of a notification under the Industrial Disputes Act.
Precedent: Judicial precedents emphasize the importance of strict interpretation of statutory provisions.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment emphasized that notifications should not be expansively construed.
Ruling: The Tribunal’s decision was overturned, confirming that the notification’s scope was limited.

Case Name: RANI Vs. NATIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY LTD
Petitioner: Rani (Claimants in Civil Appeal No.9078 of 2017) and Anand
Respondent: National Insurance Company Ltd & Offending vehicle owner
Issue Presented: Whether the claimants are entitled to enhanced compensation and if the Insurance Company should pay first and recover from the vehicle owner.
Facts of the Case: The claimants filed for enhanced compensation, asserting that the Insurance Company should pay upfront.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal awarded compensation but did not provide for direct upfront payment by the insurer.
Argument: The claimants contended that the Insurance Company should compensate first, later seeking reimbursement from the vehicle owner.
Statute: Motor Vehicles Act, CPC Order 41 Rule 33.
Rules: The case examined whether insurance companies should pay compensation first and recover later based on statutory provisions.
Precedent: The case revisited the principle of "pay and recover" and how statutory compliance influences insurance claims.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court reaffirmed that an insurer's liability is based on statutory compliance and clarified the principle of "pay first, recover later."
Ruling: The Court ruled that compensation could be paid first by the insurer.

Case Name: B. M. Ramaswamy Vs. B. M. Krishnamurthy And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner’s exclusion from the electoral roll due to procedural deficiencies violated his right to contest elections.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s request for inclusion in the electoral roll was denied due to procedural issues.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court denied inclusion in the electoral roll based on procedural errors by the authorities.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the procedural mistakes made by authorities should not lead to his exclusion from the electoral roll.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1950; Election Commission Rules.
Rules: The case analyzed the statutory requirements for electoral roll inclusion.
Precedent: The case referred to past precedents emphasizing that compliance with electoral procedures is critical to ensuring fair elections.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that non-compliance with procedural requirements could legally impact an individual's ability to contest elections.
Ruling: The ruling affirmed that strict compliance with electoral procedures is mandatory.

Case Name: Bhabhi Vs. Sheo Govind & Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent’s request for sample inspection was valid despite not providing concrete evidence of irregularities.
Facts of the Case: The petition for sample inspection was based on unverified claims and lacked material evidence of election malpractice.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court accepted the petitioner's request for sample inspection, despite a lack of material evidence.
Argument: The respondent argued for the inspection, citing potential irregularities, but failed to substantiate the claims.
Statute: Conduct of Election Rules, 1961; Election Commission Regulations.
Rules: The case examined the procedural necessity for presenting concrete allegations before requesting sample inspections.
Precedent: The ruling reflected on previous judgments stressing that vague allegations cannot form the basis for election disputes.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reiterated that procedural defects and lack of substantiation undermine the validity of the request for inspection.
Ruling: The judgment concluded that the petition was invalid.

Case Name: Kathiawar Industries Limited Vs. Jaffrabad Municipality
Issue Presented: Whether salt processed within octroi limits, but not consumed or sold locally, is liable for octroi duty.
Facts of the Case: The municipality argued that the processing of salt within octroi limits makes it subject to tax, while the petitioner claimed it was exempt due to the lack of local use.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that processed salt within municipal limits is taxable under the octroi duty laws.
Argument: The respondent contended that the transformation of salt within the octroi area qualifies as "use," thereby attracting tax.
Statute: Section 3 of the Octroi Act; Taxation principles under Entry 52, List II of the Indian Constitution.
Rules: The ruling relied on the interpretation of "use" in the context of physical transformation for exportation purposes.
Precedent: The decision set a precedent for applying octroi tax on goods undergoing modification, regardless of final destination.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision clarified that municipal taxes can apply to goods processed for export if they undergo transformation.
Ruling: The ruling confirmed that octroi duty applied to salt processed within the octroi limits.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras Vs. M/S. Madurai Mills Co. Limited
Issue Presented: Whether voluntary liquidation distributions are taxable as capital gains under Indian tax law.
Facts of the Case: The company contested the capital gains tax assessment on the distribution of assets upon liquidation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal ruled that the voluntary liquidation distributions were not subject to capital gains tax.
Argument: The respondent contended that the distribution of assets in liquidation was not a "transfer" under tax law, and thus not taxable.
Statute: Section 12B(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Taxation provisions under corporate liquidation laws.
Rules: The Court reviewed that capital gains tax would not apply to liquidation distributions unless a sale or transfer took place.
Precedent: The ruling set a precedent that liquidation distributions are not taxable unless they meet the transfer criteria under tax laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reinforced that corporate liquidation distributions are exempt from capital gains tax unless a transfer occurs.
Ruling: The Court upheld the Tribunal’s decision, ruling that the tax assessment was incorrect.

Case Name: Union of India and Anr Vs. Pfizer Limited and Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the government had the legal authority to impose the ban under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act.
Facts of the Case: The pharmaceutical companies contested the ban imposed by the government.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled in favor of the petitioners, stating that the ban lacked statutory authorization.
Argument: The petitioners claimed that the government had acted beyond its statutory powers by imposing the ban without proper legislative backing.
Statute: Section 26A of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940.
Rules: The ruling clarified that statutory authority must not exceed its scope and must be exercised within legislative boundaries.
Precedent: It reinforced the principle that government agencies must operate within their prescribed authority and comply with due process.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision clarified that statutory actions must follow procedural correctness and cannot exceed legislative mandates.
Ruling: The Court ruled that the government exceeded its jurisdiction and was not authorized to impose the ban under the statute.

Case Name: Indian Young Lawyers Association Vs. State of Kerala (Sabarimala Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the ban on women of menstruating age entering the Sabarimala Temple infringes upon gender equality.
Facts of the Case: The petitioners contested the restriction preventing women of menstruating age from entering the temple, claiming it violated.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the restriction, supporting the argument that religious customs could dictate access.
Argument: The petitioners claimed the ban violated fundamental rights to equality.
Rules: The Court examined the tension between religious freedom and constitutional guarantees of equality.
Precedent: The ruling involved a broader discussion on gender equality and the application of religious practices.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that religious practices must align with constitutional values.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the restriction on women entering the Sabarimala Temple violated constitutional rights.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Praful Desai
Issue Presented: Whether the use of video conferencing for recording witness testimony.
Facts of the Case: The prosecution applied to record the testimony of a witness who was unable to travel to India through video conferencing.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against the use of video conferencing, citing it as an improper method for recording witness testimony.
Argument: The petitioner emphasized that video conferencing could prevent delays in legal proceedings.
Rules: The ruling examined the incorporation of modern technological tools into established legal procedures.
Precedent: The Court referred to existing jurisprudence on adopting technology in legal proceedings.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court acknowledged the need for modern solutions in legal proceedings.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that video conferencing is a valid method for recording witness testimony.

Case Name: Shabnam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether undue delay in deciding a mercy petition violates the right to a timely and fair process.
Facts of the Case: Shabnam, a death row convict, challenged the delay in the rejection of her mercy petition, claiming it was cruel and inhumane.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the claim of undue delay.
Argument: Petitioner argued that undue delay in deciding mercy petitions violates Article 21.
Rules: Focused on interpreting Article 21's protection of rights to a fair process and dignity.
Precedent: Previous rulings on death row appeals, delay in execution.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court ruled that undue delay in processing a mercy petition can justify commuting the death sentence to life imprisonment.
Ruling: The Court ruled in favor of commuting Shabnam's death sentence to life imprisonment due to the inordinate delay.

Case Name: Ritesh Sinha Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether compelling the provision of a voice sample violates the protection against self-incrimination.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the demand for his voice sample, arguing that it violated his right against self-incrimination under the Constitution.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the demand for a voice sample, ruling it did not infringe upon the petitioner’s right.
Argument: The petitioner contended that forcing a voice sample would violate his right against self-incrimination.
Rules: The case considered whether a voice sample is considered self-incrimination.
Precedent: The Court considered past decisions on bodily evidence.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court ruled that providing a voice sample does not violate it is not considered testimonial evidence.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s ruling.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax II Vs. M/s. Modipon Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether the deposits made under the PLA should be treated as excise duty payments.
Facts of the Case: The issue revolves around the treatment of PLA deposits.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that PLA deposits could be treated as excise duty payments.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the deposits in the PLA account were treated as excise duty payments, qualifying them for refunds.
Statute: Section 3 of the Central Excise Act, 1944; Rule 173G of the Central Excise Rules, 1944.
Rules: The Court analyzed the nature of PLA deposits, deciding if they fulfilled the criteria.
Precedent: The ruling considered prior legal interpretations regarding excise duty payments and refunds.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that PLA deposits, once paid, should be treated as excise duty payments.
Ruling: The Court ruled that PLA deposits must be considered excise duty payments.

Case Name: Gopal Singh And Others Vs. Ujagar Singh And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the daughter's gift to her sons accelerates their estate.
Facts of the Case: The trial court ruled that the property was non-ancestral and that the gift to the sons was absolute, thus dismissing the plaintiffs' claim.
Ruling by Lower Court: The trial court ruled that the property was non-ancestral and that the gift was absolute, dismissing the plaintiffs' claims.
Argument: The plaintiffs argued that the trial court erred in treating the property as non-ancestral and that the gift to the sons was not absolute.
Statute: Customary law and principles related to property inheritance and alienation by female heirs.
Rules: The court emphasized customary laws and inheritance practices in relation to property claims.
Precedent: The ruling was based on established customary law, focusing on the relationship between ancestral claims.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized the absolute nature of the daughter's gift and confirmed that reversionary rights.
Ruling: The Privy Council dismissed the plaintiffs' appeal.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N. Sami Iyer
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court correctly ruled that the turnover should be taxed under the new regime.
Facts of the Case: The dispute centered on whether a transaction that was taxed earlier should be reassessed under the new sales tax regime.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the respondent, exempting the turnover from double taxation under the new law.
Argument: The respondent argued that taxing the turnover again would violate the principle of double taxation.
Statute: Statutory guidelines ensuring no double taxation on transactions already taxed.
Rules: The ruling emphasized that the previous taxation on the turnover under the Madras Act.
Precedent: The court reaffirmed the principle of non-double taxation, ensuring that previously taxed transactions are exempt.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s decision, emphasizing that once a transaction is taxed.

Case Name: Punj Lloyd Limited Vs. Corporate Risks India Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission's dismissal of the complaint was justified.
Facts of the Case: The respondent allegedly failed to provide appropriate coverage, leading the appellant to file a consumer complaint.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Commission rejected the claim without preliminary hearings, stating that the matter was not appropriate for consumer forums.
Argument: Corporate Risks India Pvt. Ltd. contended that the matter involved complex contractual issues outside the scope of consumer forums.
Rules: Regulations governing consumer protection claims and the scope of consumer forums in contractual disputes.
Precedent: The ruling was based on the principle that consumer forums can handle only genuine consumer disputes.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized that the complexity of contractual issues should not lead to automatic dismissal of consumer complaints.
Ruling: The dismissal of the complaint was overturned, and the case was allowed to proceed.

Case Name: State of Assam Vs. The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Respondent: The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Issue Presented: Whether the Assam government’s expansion of municipal taxation to tea estates is legally justified.
Facts of the Case: The tea estate owners argued that the imposition of municipal tax was unwarranted as they already provided all necessary amenities.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against the State, stating that municipal taxation could not apply in this case.
Argument: The petitioners contended that municipal taxation could not apply as no municipal services were being provided to the estate.
Rules: The application of municipal taxation in areas not receiving municipal services.
Precedent: Previous rulings on municipal governance and the requirement for a tangible benefit to justify taxation.
Ratio of the Decision: The imposition of tax without tangible municipal services is an abuse of power, thus violating legal standards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the tea estate was exempt from municipal taxation due to the lack of services.

Case Name: Union Public Service Commission Vs. Shristi Singh
Issue Presented: Whether UPSC’s rejection of Shristi Singh’s application based on her experience certificates was valid.
Facts of the Case: Shristi Singh challenged the UPSC’s rejection of her application, arguing that her experience was relevant and should be considered.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal found that the UPSC did not provide adequate grounds for rejecting Singh’s application.
Argument: Shristi Singh argued that her experience was valid and that the rejection lacked a fair and legal foundation.
Rules: Interpretation of the experience requirement in the context of the statutory rules and job advertisement.
Precedent: Legal precedents on whether strict adherence to eligibility requirements is always necessary.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized that strict interpretation of experience criteria should not overshadow fair eligibility consideration.
Ruling: The ruling confirmed that Singh’s rejection was not legally justified, ensuring fairness in the selection process.

Case Name: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Anr Vs. Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Anr
Petitioner: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Another
Respondent: Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether NESCO can demand past arrears from the new owner of a factory unit acquired in a liquidation sale.
Facts of the Case: NESCO demanded outstanding electricity dues from the respondent even after the respondent signed a new agreement with them.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Single Judge's decision upheld NESCO’s demand for payment of past dues, dismissing the petitioner's appeal.
Argument: The respondent contended that the new agreement with NESCO should not be burdened with the previous owner's arrears.
Rules: Examination of whether new buyers should be liable for previous debts in commercial transactions.
Precedent: Legal precedents concerning liability for unpaid debts in cases of factory acquisition and power supply agreements.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized that municipal authorities cannot arbitrarily transfer past debts unless there is a clear legal foundation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the respondent.

Case Name: Subodh Gopal Bose Vs. Ajit Kumar Haldar And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the plaintiff, as a purchaser, can annul the tenures under Section 37 of the Amending Act.
Facts of the Case: The case involves the plaintiff claiming the right to annul tenures after purchasing an estate that was sold due to arrears.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court upheld the plaintiff’s claim, permitting the annulment of the encumbrances.

Rules: The interpretation of Section 37 of the Bengal Tenancy Act concerning the sale of estates for arrears and the protection of tenure.
Precedent: Judicial precedents regarding the treatment of encumbrances during estate sales and legal protections for tenures.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reaffirmed that an estate sold for arrears is free from encumbrances unless the tenure falls within specific statutory exceptions.

Case Name: Beni Madhab Shaw Alias Benia Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner’s detention under the Essential Commodities Act was legally valid and in accordance with due process.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was detained for alleged thefts of food grains, and the detention was challenged for being unlawful under the Essential Commodities Act.

Case Name: Raghu Raj Singh Rousha Vs. M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Respondent: M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court violated principles of natural justice by deciding the matter without hearing the accused.
Facts of the Case: The complaint alleging fraud was dismissed by the magistrate; the High Court later acted under revisional jurisdiction without hearing the accused.
Ruling by Lower Court: The magistrate refused to order investigation, and the High Court intervened without giving the accused a hearing.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the High Court's order violated due process as they weren’t heard.
Rules: Revisional powers under CrPC must adhere to audi alteram partem.
Precedent: Reiterated that revisional courts cannot pass adverse orders without affording opportunity of hearing.
Ratio of the Decision: The exercise of revisional powers without hearing the accused violates the fundamental right to a fair process.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner.
